name: 3,3'-thiodipropionic acid
Reason: 3,3'-thiodipropionic acid has a melting point influenced by functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for this compound can be considered the propionic acid moiety, which has a melting point around 10°C due to the presence of a carboxyl group and a methyl group. The thiol group introduces a sulfur atom, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure, estimated at around +10°C. The methyl group introduces a bulky side chain, estimated at around +5°C due to steric hindrance and increasing the molecular volume. The carboxyl group introduces a polar carbonyl interaction, estimated at around +30°C. The presence of two additional phenyl groups can significantly increase the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +60°C.
